questions.text: A 23-year-old male had unprotected sexual intercourse with a commercial sex worker. Two weeks later, he developed a painless, indurated ulcer on the glans with painless inguinal swelling. The most appropriate diagnostic test is:

A patient presented with oral ulcers since 3 months and flaccid bullae with painful red raw erosions on the skin. Findings of a bedside test are shown. Characteristic microscopic feature of this disease is:
A 4 year old male presented with mutiple tense bullae on the body as shown below. Which of the following antigens is involved in the pathogenesis?
questions.solution:
Typical tense bullae and the string od pearl appearance in the clinical images point to a diagnosis of linear IgA disease. The underlying cause of linear IgA bullous dermatosis (LABD) is circulating IgA anti-basement membrane zone antibodies directed against the 97 kDa portion of BPAG2 (bullous pemphigoid antigen 2, also known as BP180) in the lamina lucida.

The 97 kDa subunit lies within the well-known NC16A domain of the BPAG2 molecule.

Reference: Neena Khanna, illustrated textbook of dermatology, chapter 5
